37 There are a plethora of factors that place rural communities at high risk of COVID‐19 acquisition. The facilities at rural health centers are currently inadequate to cater to the needs of rural communities at times of disaster, as indicated by Shah et al.
36 In specific, the facilities lack space, beds and equipment required for disaster relief, and the healthcare staff at rural health centers lacks proper training and expertise. Considering the fact that most rural citizens are associated with the livestock industry and have little access to healthcare facilities,
33 they are undoubtedly at increased risk of COVID‐19, especially if the virus spreads to animals in the future.
